Hello everyone! I encountered some issues while trying to solve this summable problem. I attempted to use the summable_of_ratio_norm_eventually_le strategy to address it. Then, I tried to verify the mathematical feasibility of this approach, and I found that I need to define r in a form like this:
r:=11+k+1q+1r := \frac{1}{1 + \frac{k + 1}{q + 1}}r:=1+q+1k+1​1​
where q≥bq \geq bq≥b, and bbb is a parameter that appeared when I was trying to prove the second goal.
May I ask how to solve this problem?

example (k : ℕ) (hk : 1 ≤ k) : Summable fun i ↦ (((i + k).choose k) : ℝ)⁻¹ * ((i : ℝ) + k + 1)⁻¹ := by
  apply summable_of_ratio_norm_eventually_le (r := _) -- how to do this?
  · sorry
  · unfold Filter.Eventually
    simp
    use k
    intro b hb
    have h₁ : |(b : ℝ) + 1 + k + 1| = (b + 1 + k + 1 : ℝ) := by
      norm_cast
    have h₂ : |(b : ℝ) + k + 1| = (b + k + 1 : ℝ) := by
      norm_cast
    rw [h₁, h₂]
    have h₃ : 0 < ((b + 1 + k).choose k) := by
      exact Nat.choose_pos (by omega)
    have h₄ : 0 < ((b + k).choose k) := by
      exact Nat.choose_pos (by omega)
    refine (inv_mul_le_iff₀' ?_).mpr ?_
    · norm_cast
    rw [mul_assoc, mul_comm (((b + k).choose k) : ℝ)⁻¹ _, mul_assoc]
Perhaps my approach might be incorrect. Are there any other ways to tackle this problem?

It would be good if you make this a #mwe by (1) adding imports to make it work for everyone and (2) putting sorrys in appropriate places so that your code has no errors (warnings are fine, errors are confusing). You can just edit your original post, no need to make a new one. As for the maths, your value of r doesn't seem to make sense because it seems to depend on more than the information which you have at the point where you need to declare it to make the proof rigorous. The ratio test is not allowed to use a value of r which depends on where you are in the series. So your problem is with the maths, not with Lean.

I'm really sorry — I'm not very familiar with this topic. I just found this tactic and tried to use it to solve the problem.

Generally speaking, using Mathlib as a way to learn math seems like a losing proposition. Many of the theorem statements in there are written in a way that might make them difficult to recognize even if you learned them previously; if they are new to you, this will be really, really hard.

Here is what summable_of_ratio_norm_eventually_le says, at least when applied to real-valued sequences. Suppose you have a sequence of reals (f in the Mathlib statement) and a real r<1, and you know that, for any n large enough, ∣fn+1∣≤r∣fn∣|f_{n+1}| \le r |f_n|∣fn+1​∣≤r∣fn​∣ (that is, the absolute values of consecutive terms in the sequence decrease at least geometrically); then you know that the series Σnfn\Sigma_{n} f_nΣn​fn​ is (absolutely) convergent.

The exact Mathlib statement is more general, because it mentions completeness and norms, and is written in terms of filters, but this is what it boils down to. If the above statement doesn't ring any bells, then it's unlikely that you understand a pen-and-paper proof of your goal well enough to formalize it in Mathlib.

When applied to positive sequences, you can drop the absolute values, and the criterion becomes that the ratio of two consecutive terms in the sequence is ultimately at most rrr, for some r<1r<1r<1. If this is not true in the sequence you are considering, then the theorem cannot be used (at least, not directly) to prove summability.
